report_title: Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing industry has experienced declines over the five years to 2022 amid COVID-19 (coronavirus) volatility. Industry operators manufacture axles, which is the central shaft used to connect two parallel wheels in a vehicle. They also manufacture transaxles, which combine the function of the axle, the gear changing components of a transmission and the power splitting ability of the auto differential. Industry revenue is largely tied to the production of vehicles. New car sales declined in 2020 amid the coronavirus pandemic, declining 14.7% in 2020. This decline contributed to the overall decrease in industry revenue, which is expected to decline at an annualized rate of 1.0% to $9.9 billion over the five years to 2022. However, as the economy began to recover in 2021 and continues to do so, industry revenue is expected to increase. Specifically, revenue for the industry is anticipated to grow 1.9% in 2022 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue generated for the Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing industry is expected to decline over the five years to 2022 due to the impact of COVID-19 on automobile production and new car sales.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue aided by shift to light trucks
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry revenue has been aided as automakers have shifted production schedules to manufacture more light trucks as opposed to sedans and compact cars, as larger vehicles require more expensive axles and transaxles.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2027, revenue for the industry is anticipated to increase an annualized 0.9% to $10.4 billion due to strong economic conditions and higher new car sales.
Industry employment is forecast to grow 1.0% to 19,124 workers, while the number of enterprises is expected to increase 0.5% to 89 companies over the five years to 2027.

industry_definition: The Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing industry manufactures axles, which is the central shaft used to connect two parallel wheels in a vehicle, and transaxles, which combine the function of the axle, the gear changing components of a transmission and the power splitting ability of the auto differential.
key_trends: Major automakers refined manufacturing processes to reduce operating costs, benefiting the industry
Due to the strengthening of the US dollar, industry exports are expected to contract
Rising wage costs has helped contribute to declining profitability
Industry operators have been gradually consolidating for years
Industry demand is largely dependent on the health of car sales and, thus, the overall economy

market_segmentation.segment_description: Demand from light vehicle production represents the Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing industry's largest market, accounting for an estimated 49.0% of industry revenue in 2022. Large domestic automakers such as Ford Motor Company, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and General Motors Company (GM) dominate this market. For example, according to American Axle and Manufacturing Holdings Inc.'s 2021 annual report, an estimated 37.0% of the company's revenue is accounted for by sales to GM. Overall, IBISWorld expects this market to continue to exert significant influence over the industry's performance.

Commercial vehicles include heavy-duty trucks, buses and vans. Demand from this market segment is expected to account for 10.1% of industry revenue in 2022. Given the lower domestic volume of production of commercial vehicles, this market segment has historically been overshadowed by demand from light vehicle production. Nevertheless, higher levels of commerce have increased demand for freight trucking during the five-year period, thus, bolstering this market's share of industry revenue. Overall, this market is expected to taper off over the coming years in line with domestic commercial vehicle production.

The off-highway vehicles market generally includes vehicles used for construction, agricultural and mining operations. Common examples include tractors, earthmovers and cranes. During the five-year period, demand from this market has increased at a gradual rate and has been primarily driven by a rising industrial production index. IBISWorld anticipates demand from off-highway vehicles to account for 15.5% of industry revenue in 2022.

This recent growth and strong demand conditions have brought this segment's share of revenue up to an estimated 25.4% in 2022. Although the US dollar is expected to depreciate over the five years to 2027, this share of revenue is expected to marginally decrease. Moreover, Canada and Mexico are the largest two output destinations, largely due to close proximity and USMCA membership. Combined, these two countries are expected to receive just under 85.0% of the value of industry exports in 2022.

products_and_services.product_description: The split and beam axle product segment includes front and rear axles for use in light vehicles, commercial vehicles and off-highway vehicles. Split axles represent independent axles connected by a differential; this is the predominant axle used in light vehicles. Beam axles represent a single rigid axle connecting two wheels and are more common among commercial trucks and trailers. Overall, this product segment is estimated to account for 48.1% of industry revenue in 2022.

Other products include steering axles, parts and aftermarket performance axles. IBISWorld anticipates industry revenue from other products to account for 9.8% of industry revenue in 2022. This product segment has remained relatively stable given the low level of product innovation involved with steering axles. Overall, each of these product segments are expected to have declined in 2020 amid the semiconductor shortage stemming from the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The level of production among the domestic car, truck and industrial vehicle manufacturing industries determines the performance of the Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing industry. Demand for new axles and transaxles and axle parts is highly correlated with motor vehicle production by original equipment manufacturers (OEMs). Due to the integral function of the industry's key products, they have an almost one-to-one ratio with the production of light vehicles. As a result, increases in the production and sales of motor vehicles will increase demand for axles and related parts.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Over the five years to 2022, imports are expected to increase at an annualized rate of 4.4% to $5.0 billion. In turn, imports as a share of domestic demand has risen during the current period to 40.5% of domestic demand. Axle and transaxle imports are sourced primarily from Mexico (37.0%), South Korea (17.2%), Japan (11.3%) and Canada (6.3%). Mexico remains the most dominant as automakers have opted to use relatively inexpensive Mexican labor to produce industry relevant goods.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has historically been a major hub for the axle and transaxle manufacturing industry. The region declined early during the former half of the five-year period as several Detroit facilities shuttered operations. However, as US automotive-related industries have recovered, the proportion has steadily increased. In 2022, IBISWorld estimates the Great Lakes region to account for 36.9% of industry establishments. Industry operators Dana Incorporated and American Axle and Manufacturing Holdings Inc. both maintain axle manufacturing operations in the Great Lakes region.

Additionally, there is a significant concentration of establishments in the Southeast and West regions. These regions support substantial vehicle-driving populations and provide favorable manufacturing conditions for both domestic and foreign automakers. As a result, axle and transaxle manufacturers tend to follow this geographic spread to reduce transportation costs. In 2022, IBISWorld expects the Southeast to comprise 24.7% of industry establishments, while the West is estimated to account for 15.1%. The Southeast is home to Toyota's North American headquarters, as well as the US home of German-based transmission manufacturer Schaeffler Technologies AG and Co. KG.
Lastly, the West is backed by the presence of California in this industry; the state contains an estimated 12.7% of industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry's products are subject to compliance imposed by the US Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards and Regulations.

Passed by the Obama Administration in July 2011, the Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards call for an increase in average fuel economy for cars and light trucks to 54.5 miles per gallon by model year 2025.
Beginning in 2020, the coronavirus pandemic introduced new regulations to the majority of industries in the United States.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The substantial capital necessary to enter the industry represents the largest barrier to entry due to the need for extensive manufacturing facilities, complex machinery and skilled engineers.
Achieving profitability is highly dependent on economies of scale and the ability to secure long-term purchasing contracts with major automakers.
The industry relies on research and development activities to improve cost-effectiveness and durability of products, requiring extensive research teams and testing facilities.

basis_points.basis_description: Industry operators compete on product durability, price, timeliness of delivery, technical expertise, new product innovation, operational flexibility and customer service.
Competition based on price has intensified due to operators relocating manufacturing operations abroad, primarily in Mexico, to take advantage of lower labor costs.
Competition on product innovation has intensified, leading to collaboration with auto assemblers to manufacture axles that better integrate with electric vehicles.
The importance of supply contracts plays a major role, requiring operators to produce high-volumes, low costs and consistent quality to secure long-term contracts.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four companies account for an estimated 40.5% of industry revenue in 2022.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are estimated to account for 11.7% of industry revenue in 2022, with the average industry employee earning an estimated $63,833 annually.
Purchases are expected to account for 68.1% of revenue in 2022, making up the largest expensed segment for the industry.
The level of capital costs within the industry is reflected by the degree of depreciation, which is estimated to be 2.9% of revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing industry exhibits a moderate level of capital-intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Over the five years to 2022, the Axle and Transaxle Manufacturing industry has exhibited a high level of revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technologically enabled inventory systems continue to shape the industry's technology and systems landscape.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: The largest companies in the industry focus on transaxles but most will still manufacture various axle-based products.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Strong global economic conditions have encouraged foreign consumers to purchase big-ticket items such as cars. Industry companies have experienced a surge in export revenue over the past five years.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Decreasing gas and oil prices have helped boost demand for cars, which in turns helps spur demand for axles and transaxles. Meanwhile, volatile but generally rising steel and aluminum prices have boosted industry profit.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Axle and transaxle manufacturing companies locate close to automakers, their biggest customer. Many companies are headquartered in the Great Lakes region to remain close to the Big Three US automakers in Michigan.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Labor costs in this industry are slightly inflated due to the prevalence of unionization in the industry workforce. Research and development strategies require skilled labor and high investment costs. Additionally, inventory management systems help to minimize depreciation costs.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: More demand for all wheel drive has propelled innovation in transaxle technology.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Enhanced standards are expected to increase research and development costs for axle manufacturers.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: The industry is subject to the requirements of federal, state, local and foreign environmental and occupational safety and health laws and regulations, including laws regulating air emissions, water discharge and waste management.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Average industry profit has declined to 4.5% of revenue in recent years. This is largely due to increasing prices of key metal inputs such as steel, as well as rising wage costs.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that your products and processes comply with environmental regulation? Have you had issues with compliance in the past?
FAQs.answer: Environmental requirements are a critical factor affecting industry operations. Industry operators face can incur substantial fines for not adhering to environmental regulations.

FAQs.question: Do you stay up to date on the latest technologies? How easily can you integrate these new technologies into your process?
FAQs.answer: Access to production technology will facilitate development of more cost-effective products without compromising on quality.

FAQs.question: What qualifications do your employees require? Do you provide ongoing training for your employees?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators demand highly skilled workers to conduct research and development activities in addition to supply chain management and engineering responsibilities.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is dependent on new car dealership sales? Can you expand your connections in the repair and maintenance market?
FAQs.answer: Despite general growth in the US economy, new car sales have generally declined over the five years to 2019, as recent waning consumer sentiment and rising interest rates has hindered demand for new vehicles.

FAQs.question: How have current prices of crude oil affect your company? How do you adapt to the volatility of crude oil prices?
FAQs.answer: High gasoline prices dissuade consumers from purchasing new cars and tend to increase use of public transportation services, such as buses and trains.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How has the appreciating US dollar and import penetration affected your company?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry operate in an intensely competitive, globalized market. Fluctuations in exchange rates between trading nations can greatly alter the global price competitiveness of axles and transaxles.
